notation.description: orbit of x under a group action
stabilizer of an element x under a group action

statement.p: Let G be a group and let X be a set. An action of the group G on the set X is a group homomorphism \phi \colon G\to \Perm(X). For g\in G and x\in X, we write gx to denote (\phi(g))(x).Beware of potential ambiguity in the notation `gx'. For example, when X is a group and G is a subgroup of X, the usual meaning of symbols `gx' is the product of the group elements g,x under the group operation. But in the context of an action of G on X, the value of (\phi(g))(x) may be different from the product gx. In this case, it is necessary to be explicit and write (\phi(g))(x), or use some other notation. We write \Orb(x) to denote the set \Orb(x)=\{gx\colon g\in g\}, called the orbit of x, and we write \Stab(x) to denote the set \Stab(x) = \{g\in G\colon gx=x\}, called the stabilizer of x.

Find the indicated orbits and stabilizers for each of the following group actions.
D_4 acts on the square X=\{(x,y)\in \R^2\colon -1\leq x,y\leq 1\} by rotations and and reflections. What is the orbit of (1,1)? What is the orbit of (1,0)? What is the stabilizer of (1,1)? What is the stabilizer of (1,0)?
\Z acts on \R by translation, that is, by (\phi(n))(x)= x+n. What is the orbit of 1? What is the orbit of \pi? What is the stabilizer of 1? What is the stabilizer of \pi?
Any group G acts on itself by conjugation, that is, by (\phi(g))(x)=gxg^{-1}=C_g(x) (see ). Describe the orbit and stabilizer of a group element x.

proposition.title: Orbits of a group action form a partition

statement.p: Let group G act on set X. The collection of orbits is a partition of X. We write X/G to denote the set of orbits. X/G=\{\Orb(x)\colon x\in X\}

statement.p: Let G be a group acting on a set X, and let x be an element of X. We have a one-to-one correspondence G/\Stab(x)\leftrightarrow \Orb(x) given by g\Stab(x) \leftrightarrow gx.
